The date of the court verdict sentencing Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the trial began, focusing on whether the suspect committed terrorism or a lesser offense.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court found Juraj Cintula guilty of terrorism for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, shot Fico five times during a public greeting in Handlova, causing serious injuries.
The court ruled that the attack was specifically targeted at the prime minister, meeting the criteria for terrorism under Slovak law.
Cintula admitted to shooting Fico but claimed he did not intend to kill, stating his aim was to stop policies he believed damaged Slovak freedom and culture.
The verdict of 21 years in prison is less than the maximum of life in prison, reflecting a legal distinction between terrorism and other attacks on public officials.
The case exposed deep political and societal divisions in Slovakia, particularly between Prime Minister Fico’s populist government and the liberal, pro-EU opposition.

Fico, who has been in power since 2006, has faced criticism for reducing military aid to Ukraine, strengthening ties with Russia, and reforming public media, which opponents argue undermines democratic standards.
Cintula plans to appeal the verdict, calling it 'unjust' and asserting that not all attacks on officials constitute terrorism.
Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula despite the severe consequences of the attack.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024. The attack, which occurred during a public event in Handlova, left Fico seriously injured. The court determined that the act constituted terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader, despite Cintula’s claim that he intended only to hurt Fico and not kill him. The verdict reflects deep political and societal divisions in Slovakia, with Fico's government facing criticism for policy shifts, including ending military aid to Ukraine, strengthening ties with Russia, and reforming public media. The opposition argues these changes undermine democratic standards and media freedom. Cintula claims his actions were a response to policies he believes have harmed Slovak culture and freedom, and he has stated he will appeal the verdict, calling it 'unjust'. Fico, who has forgiven Cintula, has returned to public office and continues to lead Slovakia's political landscape amid ongoing controversy.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
